audio_caption: The audio begins with a female speaker introducing herself and the topic of a biology lesson on reproduction, specifying that they will be identifying the reproductive parts of a flower. Light ambient background noise is audible throughout. The speaker then ends with an expression of hope that the listener will enjoy the lesson.

A female speaker begins by stating the lesson objectives, which include stating the different parts of a flower and identifying the male and female parts. Then, she adds that she is sure everyone has gone through classification. The clip ends.

The audio begins with a calm, educational voice, likely female, discussing angiosperms and their flowers, describing them as specialized structures used for reproduction. She defines a flower as a modified part of a stem where primary sex organs are found.

The clip begins with a female speaker describing a picture of a plant with flowers, referring to it as an angiosperm and stating that most listeners have probably seen flowers in various locations. She then transitions to discussing the parts of a flower.

The audio begins with a female speaker describing the parts of a flower, as indicated by the phrase "as you can see from this picture." She identifies the stigma, style, and ovary, and then proceeds to point out the anther.

The audio clip features a single speaker, who seems to be female, describing parts of a flower. She identifies "filaments," describing them as "rod-like structures" holding the anther. Her tone is informative and instructional.

The audio clip features a single, calm-toned female speaker describing parts of a flower. She identifies the petals as "very attractive in most flowers" and the sepal as "normally green." She continues to name more parts, including the "thalamus," also known as the "receptacle," and the "pedicel." The speaker summarizes that the pedicel is the part you hold when you cut the flower. She mentions that "we have the pedicel" and "the receptacle."

The audio begins with a female speaker describing the parts of a flower, referencing "the calyx, the sepals" and "corolla." She describes the sepals as green parts, and the corolla as the attractive colored petals. Then the speaker moves on to describing the stamen and the pistil, noting the anther and filaments are parts of the stamen. The pistil, she says, is composed of the stigma, style, and ovary. The speech ends on a concluding "okay."

A female speaker gives instructions for cutting a flower and observing its parts. She advises to cut a longitudinal section starting at the base and along the carpel to the stigma, observing and drawing the flower's internal parts carefully. She mentions being careful not to destroy other floral parts. Then, she says, "Now this is what you see." The recording contains low-level background noise throughout the speech.

The audio features one speaker, likely a female, speaking in an educational tone as she describes the internal parts of a flower, mentioning the stigma, style, ovary, anthers, and filaments. The speaker seems to be pointing to these parts while describing their appearance and location.

The clip features a single female speaker in a conversational tone, teaching someone to "get the reproductive parts of a flower." She identifies and describes "the anther" as carrying "the pollen grains," then discusses "the filaments" and how they form the male part of the flower.  Moving to another part of the flower, she discusses "the pistil" and explains its components: "the stigma, the style, and the ovary." The clip concludes by mentioning that the ovary contains ovules.

The clip begins with one female speaker summarizing information, stating that the stamen "refers to the male reproductive organs." They continue to describe the parts of the stamen in an informative tone. This female speaker then discusses the pistil, or female reproductive organ, and its parts.

The audio clip starts with a female speaker summarizing the parts of a flower they have discussed. She speaks in an educational tone, and concludes with a question: "What are the functions of a flower?". The speaker then thanks the listener, and says: "See you in our next lesson."
